msgSnippet: Hi, I use JUnit while I develop so I write test cases for almost every class I write.  If you use JUnit from the beginning and not after 4 month of development

Subject: Re: [junit] Choosing A Right Class.

From: Vladimir Bossicard <vladimir@...>

Hi,

I use JUnit while I develop so I write test cases for almost every class I
write.  If you use JUnit from the beginning and not after 4 month of
development process (everybody know, writing tests is boring...) you will
have a lot of useful test classes.

But if you're starting after the development, I would closely work with the
QA: everytime an error is discovered I would go through every method involved
and write tests for these methods. You won't have test cases for every classe
and every method but you will have tests for problematic methods (assuming
that easy methods are coded without errors...)

My advice is: don't trust your code if you haven't test it!  Writing a test
cost almost nothing comparing with the time needed to manually debug the
code.

My 2 cents

Vladimir
subject: Re: [junit] Choosing A Right Class.
